basis on which the calcareous skeleton is moulded,is not a body of
constant shape, provided with organs having a fixed relation on to
another, but is a mass of almost homogeneous sarcode, which in the
living state is continuously undergoing changes of form, one part
extending itself into pseudopodia, whilst another undergoes a
corresponding contraction, a strong<s>,</s> <u>a priori</u> improbability is seen to
exist, that, in animals of such organisation, the form of the component
segments should possess that value as a specific character, which
it can only derive from constancy.

53  Besides those regular markings of the surface, which correspond
to the division of the interior into cells, a peculiar aspect is frequently
given to it, by the deposit of calcareous thickenings, which are sometimes
irregular, but which occasionally present an approach to symmetry.
The most remarkable example I have met-with, of this kind of
addition, is delineated in Plate X, Fig 8; in which it will be seen that
the deposit has taken place in radial lines disposed with a certain
degree of regualrity. But in Figs 1 and 5 which represent specimens
whose surface is far less altered by these deposits, no such symmetry
presents itself; and other specimens in my possession exhibit the
